articles.headline: Facebook Looks to Become Big Fish in Another Big Pond
articles.snippet: The acquisition is part of its effort to create a series of applications on a user’s mobile device instead of relying on its core social network alone.
articles.abstract: The acquisition is part of its effort to create a series of applications on a user’s mobile device instead of relying on its core social network alone.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Facebook is already the world’s biggest social network. Now it wants to be the biggest player in a new global field by buying WhatsApp, the global leader in mobile messaging.

articles.headline: An Aggressive Fed Faces Criticism on Wall Street
articles.snippet: Even though the Federal Reserve’s economic stimulus has benefited Wall Street’s bottom line, top bankers and big investors remain some of the central bank’s most vehement critics.
articles.abstract: Even though the Federal Reserve’s economic stimulus has benefited Wall Street’s bottom line, top bankers and big investors remain some of the central bank’s most vehement critics.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:41 p.m. | Every time Janet L. Yellen, the chairwoman of the Federal Reserve, testifies in Congress, she can expect some senators to scoff and representatives to question.

articles.headline: The Hefty Yoke of Student Loan Debt
articles.snippet: As student loan debt continues to rise, the loans’ underwriting standards remain almost nonexistent, and the economy may pay the price.
articles.abstract: As student loan debt continues to rise, the loans’ underwriting standards remain almost nonexistent, and the economy may pay the price.
articles.lead_paragraph: More than five years after the binge of irresponsible lending led to the credit crisis and Great Recession, the amount of consumer debt in the United States has begun to rise again, but with an important difference. This time the credit standards appear far tougher. Those who should not borrow generally do not.

articles.headline: For Facebook, It’s Users First and Profits Later
articles.snippet: The social networking giant’s agreement to buy the messaging start-up WhatsApp for up to $19 billion is risky, but follows a trend in valuing the number of users over revenue.
articles.abstract: The social networking giant’s agreement to buy the messaging start-up WhatsApp for up to $19 billion is risky, but follows a trend in valuing the number of users over revenue.
articles.lead_paragraph: Technology companies have always been paranoid about missing the next big thing, be it email, e-commerce or social media.

articles.headline: Comcast’s Web of Lobbying and Philanthropy
articles.snippet: The company is beginning a carefully orchestrated campaign, seeking support from members of Congress, state officials and leaders of nonprofit and minority-led groups.
articles.abstract: The company is beginning a carefully orchestrated campaign, seeking support from members of Congress, state officials and leaders of nonprofit and minority-led groups.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Only a few hours had passed after the $45 billion merger between Comcast and Time Warner Cable was announced last week when an early voice emerged endorsing the giant deal.

articles.headline: Founders of an Anti-Facebook Are Won Over
articles.snippet: The co-founders of WhatsApp are not brash young Silicon Valley entrepreneurs. They are just two guys who wanted to create a simple messaging service.
articles.abstract: The co-founders of WhatsApp are not brash young Silicon Valley entrepreneurs. They are just two guys who wanted to create a simple messaging service.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Jan Koum fled the former Soviet Union with his mother when he was 16, leaving his father behind. He worked in the engineering trenches for a decade at Yahoo before starting out on his own. When he was a young man growing up in Mountain View, Calif., his family relied on food stamps to get by.
articles.byline: By Brian X. Chen and Vindu Goel

articles.headline: Egypt Extends Its Crackdown to Journalists
articles.snippet: The military government has been detaining reporters, as well as other perceived enemies like activists and Islamists.
articles.abstract: The military government has been detaining reporters, as well as other perceived enemies like activists and Islamists.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — The three men, wearing white prison scrubs in metal cages reserved for criminal suspects, listened to the list of explosive charges accusing them of aiding a plot to undermine Egypt’s national security.

articles.headline: Converts Join With Militants in Kiev Clash
articles.snippet: Groups of young men with far-right political affiliations in Ukraine have provided much of the front-line muscle in increasingly bloody clashes with the police.
articles.abstract: Groups of young men with far-right political affiliations in Ukraine have provided much of the front-line muscle in increasingly bloody clashes with the police.
articles.lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — As the center of the Ukrainian capital tipped into a maelstrom of gunfire and blood on Thursday, a man wearing a helmet stood on a street corner near Independence Square, the epicenter of the violence, holding a leaf of printer paper.
articles.byline: By Andrew Higgins and Andrew E. Kramer

articles.headline: Ukraine Has Deal, but Both Russia and Protesters Appear Wary
articles.snippet: President Viktor F. Yanukovych agreed to reduced powers and Parliament moved to free his imprisoned rival, but many protesters want him to resign.
articles.abstract: President Viktor F. Yanukovych agreed to reduced powers and Parliament moved to free his imprisoned rival, but many protesters want him to resign.
articles.lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — A deal aimed at ending a lethal spiral of violence in Ukraine began to show serious strains late Friday just hours after it had been signed, with angry protesters shouting down opposition members of Parliament who negotiated the accord and a militant leader threatening armed attacks if President Viktor F. Yanukovych did not step down by morning.
articles.byline: By Andrew Higgins and Andrew E. Kramer

articles.headline: Detroit Outlines Map to Solvency, Stressing Repair
articles.snippet: The city presented its bankruptcy judge with the first official road map to its future: a plan for settling its debt and making Detroit livable again.
articles.abstract: The city presented its bankruptcy judge with the first official road map to its future: a plan for settling its debt and making Detroit livable again.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Seven months after this city entered bankruptcy, its leaders on Friday presented a federal judge with the first official road map to Detroit’s future — documents designed to show how it aims to settle its $18 billion debt to creditors and make itself livable again.
articles.byline: By Monica Davey and Mary Williams Walsh

articles.headline: Fed Misread Crisis in 2008, Records Show
articles.snippet: The transcripts provide new insights into the debates, miscalculations and actions of the Federal Reserve in assessing and countering the financial crisis.
articles.abstract: The transcripts provide new insights into the debates, miscalculations and actions of the Federal Reserve in assessing and countering the financial crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On the morning after Lehman Brothers filed for bankruptcy in 2008, most Federal Reserve officials still believed that the American economy would keep growing despite the metastasizing financial crisis.

articles.headline: Send a Payment With Square Cash, the Service That’s Free, for Now
articles.snippet: The service from the mobile payment company Square does not charge a fee, a rare benefit. But the downside is that you cannot use a credit card.
articles.abstract: The service from the mobile payment company Square does not charge a fee, a rare benefit. But the downside is that you cannot use a credit card.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s rare that any new product or service quickly and simply makes our financial lives a whole lot easier. It’s rarer still that the offering is free.
